case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Mathadhipati of Shirur Math

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 38 of 1953 filed under article 132 of the Constitution from Madras High Court judgment dated 13th December 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 38 of 1953. Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 13th December, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature, Madras, in Civil Miscella

facts.text: Madras High Court allowed petition under article 226 on 13th December 1951 and directed writ of prohibition against appellant proceeding with settlement of scheme for Shirur Math.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is directed against a judgment of a Division Bench of the Madras High Court, dated the 13th of December, 1951, by which the learned Judges allowed petition, presented by the respondent under article 226 of the Constitution, and directed a writ of prohibition to issue in his favour prohibiting the appellant from proceeding with the settlement of a scheme in companynection with a Math, known as the Shirur Math, of which the petitioner happens to be the head or superior.

facts.text: Petition filed when Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act II of 1927 was in force against Hindu Religious Endowments Board which initiated proceedings under section 61.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at the outset that the petition was filed at a time when the Madras Hindu Religion Endowments Act  Act II of 1927 , was in force and the writ was prayed for against the Hindu Religious Endowments Board companystituted under that Act, which -was the predecessor in authority of the present appellant and had initiated proceedings for settlement of a scheme against the petitioner under section 61 of the said Act.

facts.text: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act 1951 came into force on 27th August 1951.

anchor.surface_text: While the petitions were still pending, the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act,, 1951  hereinafter called the New Act , was passed by the Madras Legislature and came into force on the 27th of August, 1951.

facts.text: Shirur Math is one of eight Maths at Udipi, South Kanara, founded by Shri Madhwacharya.

anchor.surface_text: The Math, known as Shirur Math, of which the petitioner is the superior or Mathadhipati, is one of the eight Maths situated at Udipi in the district of South Kanara and they are reputed to have been founded by Shri Madhwacharya, the well-known exponent of dualistic theism in the Hindu Religion.

facts.text: Petitioner installed as Mathadhipati in 1919 when minor, assumed management in 1926.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was installed as Mathadhipati in the year 1919, when he was still a minor, and he assumed management after companying of age some time in 1926.

facts.text: Math heavily in debt in 1926; cleared large portion between 1926-1930.

anchor.surface_text: At that time the Math was heavily in debt. Between 1926 and 1930 the Swami succeeded in clearing off a large portion of the debt.

facts.text: In 1931, petitioner took over Shri Krishna Math management, incurred debts for Pariyayam.

anchor.surface_text: In 1931, however, came the 1009 turn of his taking over management of the Shri Krishna Math and he had had to incur debts to meet the heavy expenditure attendant on the Pariyayam ceremonies,

facts.text: In 1946, second Pariyayam, debts mounted to nearly a lakh of rupees due to scarcity and high prices.

anchor.surface_text: but troubles again arose in 1946, which was the year of the second Pariyayam of the Swami. Owing to scarcity and the high prices of companymodities at that time, the Swami had to borrow money to meet the expenditure and the debts mounted up to nearly a lakh of rupees.

facts.text: Hindu Religious Endowments Board under 1927 Act directed appointment of competent manager under s.61A.

anchor.surface_text: The Hindu Religious Endowments Board, functioning under the Earlier Act of 1927, intervened at this stage and in exercise of its powers under section 61 -A of the Act called upon the Swami to appoint a companypetent manager to manage the affairs of the institution.

facts.text: Sripath Achar appointed agent, Power of Attorney executed on 24th December 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in pursuance of the direction of the Board, one Sripath Achar was appointed an agent and a Power of Attorney was executed in his favour on the 24th of December, 1948.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges agent disregarded Mahant's wishes, did not submit accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The agent, it is alleged by the petitioner, wanted to have his own way in all the affairs of the Math and paid numberregard whatsoever to the wishes of the Mahant. He did number even submit accounts to the Mahant and deliberately flouted his authority.

facts.text: Swami served notice terminating agency on 26th September 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In this state of affairs the Swami,, on the 26th of September, 1950, served a numberice upon the agent terminating his agency and calling upon him to hand over to the Mathadhipati all account papers and vouchers relating to the institution together with the cash in hand.

facts.text: Petitioner filed suit on 4th October 1950 against agent in Sub-Court South Kanara for accounts, injunction.

anchor.surface_text: On the 4th of October, 1950, the petitioner filed a suit against the agent in the Sub,Court of South Kanara for recovery of the account books and other articles belonging to the Math, for rendering an account of the management and also for an injunction restraining the said agent from interfering with the affairs of the Math under companyour of the 1010 authority companyferred by the Power of Attorney which the plaintiff had cancelled.

facts.text: Agent filed application to Board on 3rd October 1950 complaining against cancellation.

anchor.surface_text: The said Sripath Achar anticipating this suit filed an application to the Board on the 3rd of October, 1950, companyplaining against the cancellation of the Power of Attorney and his management of the Math.

facts.text: Board issued notice on 4th October 1950 for inquiry on 24th October 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Board on the 4th October, 1950, issued a numberice to the Swami proposing to inquire into the matter on the 24th of October following at 2 p.m. at Madras and requesting the Swami either to apppear in person or by a pleader.

facts.text: Swami replied on 21st October 1950 that matter sub judice.

anchor.surface_text: To this the Swami sent a reply on 21st October, 1950, stating that the subject-matter of the very enquiry was before the companyrt in the original suit filed by him and as the matter was sub judice the enquiry should be put off.

facts.text: Board initiated suo moto proceedings under s.62 on 6th November 1950 for scheme due to mismanagement.

anchor.surface_text: The Board, it appears, dropped that enquiry, but without waiting for the result of the suit, initiated proceedings suo moto under section 62 of the Earlier Act and issued a numberice upon the Swami on the 6th of November, 1950, stating that it had reason to believe that the endowments of the said Math were being mismanaged and that a scheme should be framed for the administration of its affairs.

facts.text: Notice served by affixture, inquiry fixed for 8th December 1950.

anchor.surface_text: . The numberice was served by affixture on the Swami and the 8th of December, 1950, was fixed as the date of enquiry.

facts.text: Petition filed in Madras High Court on 12th February 1951 for writ of prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: On the 12th of February, 1951, the peti- tioner filed the petition, out of which this appeal arises, in the High Court of Madras, praying for a writ of prohibition to prohibit the Board from taking further steps in the matter of settling a scheme for the administration of the Math.

facts.text: High Court held Board's action perverse exercise of jurisdiction on merits.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, it was held that in the circumstances of the case the action of the Board was a perverse exercise of its jurisdiction and that it should 1012 number be allowed to proceed in regard to the settlement of the scheme.

facts.text: High Court declared several sections of New Act ultra vires Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: On the companystitutional issues raised in the case, the learned Judges pronounced quite a number of sections of the New Act to be ultra vires the Constitution by reason of their being in companyflict with the fundamental rights of the petitioner guaranteed under articles 19 1  f , 25, 26 and 27 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal on certificate under Art 132(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Commisioner has number companye up on appeal before us on the strength of a certificate granted by the High Court under article 132 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant confined arguments to constitutional points, did not challenge HC findings on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate-General for Madras, who appeared in support of the appeal, companyfined his arguments exclusively to the companystitutional points involved in this case. Although he had put in an application to. urge grounds other than the companystitutional grounds, that application was number pressed and he did number challen the findings of fact upon which the High Court based its decision on the merits of the petition.

facts.text: Mathadhipati holds beneficial interest in Math property, blending office and property.

anchor.surface_text: Thus in the companyception of Mahantship, as in Shebaitship, both the elements of office and property, of duties and personal interest are blended together and neither can be detached from the other.

On the other hand, if it is a tax, as this particular tax has number been provided for in any specific entry in any of the three lists,

anchor.surface_text: Having thus disposed of the general companytentions that were raised in this appeal, we will proceed number to examine the specific grounds that have been urged by the parties before us in regard to the decision of the High Court so far as it declared several sections of the new Act to be ultra vires the Constitution by reason of their companyflicting with the fundamental rights of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, it was held that in the circumstances of the case the action of the Board was a perverse exercise of its jurisdiction and that it should 1012 number be allowed to proceed in regard to the settlement of the scheme.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 5th of February, 1951. On the 12th of February, 1951, the peti- tioner filed the petition, out of which this appeal arises, in the High Court of Madra

arguments.court_reasoning: Examined specific sections; some upheld, some struck down.

arguments.claim: The respondent as Mathadhipati does not have a right to property in the legal sense in the religious institution and its endowments to claim protection under Article 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: As regards article 19 1   f  of the Constitution, the question that requires companysideration is, whether the respondent as Mathadhipati has a right to property in the legal sense,, in the religious institution and its endowments which would enable him to claim the -protection of this article ?

arguments.court_reasoning: Mahantship blends office and property; beneficial interest recognized by precedents.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court prefers to proceed assuming it applies to concrete rights without final opinion.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the Act describes the powers of the Commissioner in respect to religious endowments and they include power to pass any orders that may be deemed n

anchor.surface_text: Thus in the companyception of Mahantship, as in Shebaitship, both the elements of office and property, of duties and personal interest are blended together and neither can be detached from the other.

arguments.court_reasoning: Encroaches on disposal powers over surplus; impairs dignity.

arguments.court_reasoning: Deprives Mahant of administration without mismanagement prerequisite.

arguments.claim: Chapter VI sections 63-69 on notification are void; no court access.

arguments.claim: Board's proceedings not bona fide; actuated by bias.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged inter alia that the Board was actuated by bias against the petitioner and the action taken by it with regard to the settling of a scheme was number a bona fide act at all.

arguments.claim: Provisions of the Act conflict with Articles 19(1)(f) and 26.

anchor.surface_text: The main companytention, however, was that having regard to the fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution in matters of religion and religious institutions belonging to particular religious denominations, the law regulating the framing of a scheme interfering with the management of the Math and its affairs by the Mathadhipati companyflicted with the provisions of art- icles 19 1   f  and 26 of the Constitution

court_response_anchor.surface_text: uction as the Commissioner or the Area Committee might give in that companynection. If the trustee is to be guided but number fettered by such directi

holdings.text: The Mathadhipati holds his position as a blend of office and property with beneficial personal interest protected as property right under Article 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: Thus in the conception of Mahantship, as in Shebaitship, both the elements of office and property, of duties and personal interest are blended together and neither can be detached from the other. The personal or beneficial interest of the Mahant in the endowments attached to an institution is manifested in his large powers of disposal and administration and his right to create derivative tenures in respect to endowed properties and these and other rights of a similar character invest the office of the Mahant with .the character of proprietary right which, though anomalous to some extent, is still a genuine legal right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogizes Mahantship to Shebaitship per Judicial Committee precedents; property word in Constitution given wide connotation including beneficial interests.

holdings.text: Article 19(1)(f) applies to concrete as well as abstract rights of property.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes without final decision as not argued; prior court practice supports.

holdings.text: Article 25 protects the Mathadhipati's freedom to practice and propagate religion as head of spiritual fraternity.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Mathadhipati is individual person; propagation by persons protected regardless of institutional context.

holdings.text: A Math and its spiritual fraternity constitute a religious denomination or section thereof under Article 26.

anchor.surface_text: As regards article 26, the first question is, what is the precise meaning or connotation of the expression religious denomination and whether a Math could come within this expression... The Math or the spiritual fraternity represented by it can legitimately come within the purview of this article.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defines denomination per dictionary; Udipi Maths founded by Madhwacharya followed by Sivalli Brahmins as section.

holdings.text: Under Article 26(b), religious denominations manage own affairs in matters of religion (rites, rituals essential to faith), distinct from property administration under 26(c),(d).

anchor.surface_text: The other thing that remains to be considered in regard to article 26 is, what is the scope of clause (b) of the article which speaks of management of its own affairs in matters of religion ? ... questions merely relating to administration of properties belonging to a religious group or institution are not matters of religion to which clause (b) of the article applies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual distinction in clauses; religion includes beliefs, rituals, practices subject to constitutional limits; secular activities regulable.

holdings.text: Section 21 of the Act is ultra vires Articles 25 and 26.

anchor.surface_text: We agree, however, with the High Court in the view taken by it about section 21. This section empowers the Commissioner and his subordinate officers... We think that as the section stands, it interferes with the fundamental rights of the Mathadhipati and the denomination of which he is head guaranteed under articles 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unrestricted entry to sacred places interferes with rites; no safeguards like notice or timing; s91 not saving.

holdings.text: Sections 30(2) and 31 are invalid as unreasonable restrictions on Mahant's property rights under Article 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: We think that sections 30(2) and 31 have been rightly held to be invalid by the High Court... This is an unreasonable restriction on the Mahants right of property which is blended with his office.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Encroaches on disposal of surplus for institutional purposes and propagation; impairs dignity.

holdings.text: Section 55(1) and (2) invalid as unwarranted restrictions on Mahant's rights over Pathakanikas.

anchor.surface_text: The first clause of section 55 lays down that such Pathakanikas shall be spent only for the purposes of the Math. This is an unwarranted restriction on the property right of the Mahant... The same objection can be raised against clause (2) of the section...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Personal gifts generally disposable by Mahant; general rule not limited by custom without specification.

anchor.surface_text: Section 56 has been rightly invalidated by the High Court. It makes provision of an extremely drastic character... Such restriction would be opposed to the provision of article 26(d) of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allows appointment of manager without mismanagement prerequisite; deprives administration right.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore, in agreement with High Court that these sections should be hold to be void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drastic takeover without court access; no natural justice.

holdings.text: The contribution under Section 76 is a fee, not a tax.

anchor.surface_text: If the contribution payable under section 76 of the Act is a fee, it may come under entry 47... the distinction between a tax and a fee lies primarily in the fact that a tax is levied as a part of a common burden, while a fee is a payment for a special benefit or privilege.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quid pro quo for government services to institutions; uniform, based on costs unlike capacity-based tax.

anchor.surface_text: The other is, that the contribution being a tax or imposition... it comes within the mischief of article 27... As we hold it is a fee for services to all religious institutions generally.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fee not tax promoting particular religion; services to all institutions, proceeds for administration not specific religion.

holdings.text: Sections 20, 23, 24, 25, 26, 28, 29, 53, 54, 58, 59, 70, 89, 99 are constitutionally valid as applied to Maths.

anchor.surface_text: Having thus disposed of the general contentions... Section 20... some amount of control... is certainly necessary... We are unable, therefore, to agree with the view expressed by the learned Judges... Section 99... is beneficial to the trustee...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable supervision, registers, alienation controls, budgets, appeals provided; do not infringe fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: Privy Council 1 , says, a manager or custodian, of the institution who has to discharge the duties of a trustee and is answerable as such but he is number a mere manager and it would number be right to describe Mahantship as a mere office. A superior of a Math has number only duties to discharge in companynection with the endowment but he has a personal interest of a beneficial character which is sanctioned by custom and is much larger than that of a Shebait in the debutter property.

precedents.cited_proposition: pronouncements of the Judicial Committee on position of Mathadhipati

precedents.citation: Vidya Varuthi v. Balusami, 48 I. A. 302

anchor.surface_text: Vide Vidya Varuthi v. Balusami, 48 I. A. 302 Vide Monahai v. Bhupendra, 60 Cal. 452.  3  63 I.A. 448.  4  70 I.A. 57. 1019 The effect of the first two decisions, as the Privy Council pointed out in the last case, was to emphasise the propriet ary element in the Shebaiti right and to show that though in some respects an anomaly, it was an anomaly to be accepted as having been admitted into Hindu ,law from an early date.

precedents.cited_proposition: Mathadhipati holds property as manager or custodian with personal beneficial interest

anchor.surface_text: Vide Monahai v. This view was adopted in its entirety by this companyrt in Angurbala v. Debabrata  1 , and what was said in that case in respect to Shebaiti right companyld, with equal propriety, be applied to the office of a Mahant.

The personal or beneficial interest of the Mahant in the endowments attached to an institution is manifested in his large powers of disposal and administration and his right to create derivative tenures in respect to endowed properties and these and other rights of a similar character invest the office of the Mahant with .the character of proprietary right which, though anomalous to some extent, is still a genuine legal right.

The personal or beneficial interest of the Mahant in the endowments attached to an institution is manifested in his large powers of disposal and administration and his right to create derivative tenures in respect to endowed properties and these and other rights of a similar character invest the office of the Mahant with .the character of proprietary right which, though anomalous to some extent, is still a genuine legal right.

precedents.citation: The State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose II Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1952, decided by this companyrt on the 17th December, 1953 , 1954 S.C.R. 587

anchor.surface_text: In the case of The State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose II   Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1952, decided by this companyrt on the 17th December, 1953 , an opinion was expressed by Patanjali Sastri C. J. that article 19 1   f  of the Constitution is companycerned only with the abstract right and capacity to acquire, hold and dispose of property and that it has numberrelation to companycrete property rights. This, it may be numbered, was an expression of opinion by the learned Chief Justice alone and it was number the decision of the companyrt for out of the other four learned Judges who together with the Chief Justice companystituted the Bench, two did number definitely agree with this view, while the remaining two did number express any opinion one way or the other.

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: article 19(1)(f) concerns abstract right to property (opinion of CJ)

anchor.surface_text: Vide Davie v. Benson 133 U.S 333 at 342. 1024 doctrine or belief. A religion may number only lay down a companye of ethical rules for its followers to accept, it might prescribe rituals and observances, ceremonies and modes of worship which are regarded as integral parts of religion, and these forms and observances might extend even to matters of food and dress.

precedents.cited_holding: religion refers to views of relation to Creator

precedents.citation: Adelaide Company V. The Commonwealth 67 C.L.R. 116, 127

anchor.surface_text: Vide Adelaide Company V. The Commonwealth 67 C.L.R. 116, 127 1025 legislate for social welfare and reform even though by so doing it might interfere with religious practices. The learned Attorney-General lays stress upon clause  2  a  of the article and his companytention is that all secular activities, which may be associated with religion but do number really companystitute an essential part of it, are amenable to State regulation.

precedents.case_name: Adelaide Company of Jehovah's Witnesses v. Commonwealth
precedents.cited_proposition: freedom of religion protects acts done in pursuance of religion

precedents.citation: Minersville School District, Board of Education, etc. v. Gobitis 310 U.S. 586

anchor.surface_text: Minersville School District, Board of Education, etc. v. Gobitis 2 . In that case two small children, Lillian and William Gobitis, were expelled from the public school of Minersville, Pennsylvania, for refusing to salute the national flag as part of the daily exercise.

precedents.cited_proposition: flag salute requirement does not infringe religious freedom
precedents.cited_holding: flag salute not violation of religion

precedents.citation: West Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnette 319 U.S. 624

anchor.surface_text: West Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnette 1 . There it was held overruling the earlier decision referred to above that the action of a State in making it companypulsory for children in public schools to salute the flag and pledge allegiance companystituted a violation of the First and the Fourteenth Amendments.

precedents.case_name: West Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnette
precedents.cited_proposition: flag salute compulsory violates religious freedom (overruling Gobitis)

anchor.surface_text: Murdock v. Pennsylvania 2 . Here also the petitioners were Jehovas Witnesses and they went about from door to door in the city of Jeannette distributing literature and soliciting people to purchase certain religious books and pamphlets,

precedents.cited_proposition: licence tax on religious colporteurs invalid

anchor.surface_text: Jones v. Opelika 1 , and it was held that a city ordinance, which required that licence be procured and taxes paid for the business of selling books and pamphlets on the streets from house to house, was applicable to a member of a religious Organisation who was engaged in selling the printed propaganda, pamphlets without having companyplied with the provisions of the ordinance.

precedents.cited_proposition: licence for selling religious literature applicable (overruled later)

precedents.citation: Matthews v. Chicory Marketing Board 60 C.L.R. 263, 276

anchor.surface_text: Matthews v. Chicory Marketing Board 1 . A tax, according to the learned Chief Justice, is a companypulsory exaction of money by public authority for public purposes enforceable by law and is number payment for services rendered. This definition brings out, in our opinion, the esential characteristics of a tax as distinguished from other forms of imposition which, in a general sense, are included within it.

precedents.cited_holding: compulsory exaction for public purposes, not for services

precedents.citation: Lower Mainland Dairy v. Crystal Dairy Ltd. 1933 C. 168

anchor.surface_text: Vide Lower Mainland Dairy v. Crystal Dairy Ltd. 1933 C. 168. 1041 object of a tax is number to companyfer any special benefit upon any particular individual, there is, as it is said, numberelement of quid pro quo between the taxpayer and the public authority 1 . Another feature of taxation it that as it is a part of the companymon burden, the quantum of imposition upon the taxpayer depends generally upon his capacity to pay.

precedents.case_name: Lower Mainland Dairy v. Crystal Dairy Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: essence of taxation is compulsion without consent

outcome.relief_summary: High Court writ of prohibition upheld on unchallenged merits (prohibiting scheme settlement); High Court declarations on constitutional invalidity of Act sections partly reversed (some sections upheld as valid, others confirmed ultra vires)
directions: Order of High Court stands on merits

anchor.surface_text: Thus in the conception of Mahantship, as in Shebaitship, both the elements of office and property, of duties and personal interest are blended together and neither can be detached from the other. The personal or beneficial interest of the Mahant in the endowments attached to an institution is manifested in his large powers of disposal and administration and his right to create derivative tenures in respect to endowed properties and these and other rights of a similar character invest the office of the Mahant with .the character of proprietary right which, though anomalous to some extent, is still a genuine legal right.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n
We hold therefore, in agreement with High Court that these sections should be hold to be void.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n

If the contribution payable under section 76 of the Act is a fee, it may come under entry 47... the distinction between a tax and a fee lies primarily in the fact that a tax is levied as a part of a common burden, while a fee is a payment for a special benefit or privilege.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n
The other is, that the contribution being a tax or imposition... it comes within the mischief of article 27... As we hold it is a fee for services to all religious institutions generally.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n

Having thus disposed of the general contentions... Section 20... some amount of control... is certainly necessary... We are unable, therefore, to agree with the view expressed by the learned Judges... Section 99... is beneficial to the trustee...

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n

As regards article 26, the first question is, what is the precise meaning or connotation of the expression religious denomination and whether a Math could come within this expression... The Math or the spiritual fraternity represented by it can legitimately come within the purview of this article.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n

The other thing that remains to be considered in regard to article 26 is, what is the scope of clause (b) of the article which speaks of management of its own affairs in matters of religion ? ... questions merely relating to administration of properties belonging to a religious group or institution are not matters of religion to which clause (b) of the article applies.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n

We agree, however, with the High Court in the view taken by it about section 21. This section empowers the Commissioner and his subordinate officers... We think that as the section stands, it interferes with the fundamental rights of the Mathadhipati and the denomination of which he is head guaranteed under articles 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n
We think that sections 30(2) and 31 have been rightly held to be invalid by the High Court... This is an unreasonable restriction on the Mahants right of property which is blended with his office.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n

The first clause of section 55 lays down that such Pathakanikas shall be spent only for the purposes of the Math. This is an unwarranted restriction on the property right of the Mahant... The same objection can be raised against clause (2) of the section...

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n

Section 56 has been rightly invalidated by the High Court. It makes provision of an extremely drastic character... Such restriction would be opposed to the provision of article 26(d) of the Constitution.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us. It is n

edges.explanation: p5 emphasises proprietary element in Shebaiti right, which supports h1's finding that Mathadhipati holds position as blend of office and property with beneficial interest protected under Article 19(1)(f)
p5 on proprietary element in Shebaiti right supports recognizing similar property right for Mathadhipati as per i1
p6 adopts view on Shebaiti right applicable to Mahantship, directly supporting h1's characterization of Mathadhipati's proprietary interest under Article 19(1)(f)
p6 extending Shebaiti proprietary view to Mahantship supports property right claim for Mathadhipati in i1
